abstract.p: Henry Alford article on attending celebrity events at department stores; drawing (M)

block.p: Do celebrity appearances and special events at department stores fulfill any function other than the purely commercial? I never thought so -- until two autumns ago. One sunshiny September day, I was crossing 37th Street when I saw three militant Hummer vehicles barreling down Fifth Avenue. Upon noticing that each of the vehicles was bedecked with flags reading ''Hanes Resilience hosiery'' and with a bevy of preternaturally attractive women, I feared that fashion models had mobilized, with pantyhose as their broadswords. But a moment later reality set in. I realized that a promotional campaign had been loosed upon midtown like a virus and that I had become a most willing human host.

The women alit from the Humm-V's. I followed them into Lord & Taylor, where I learned that the supermodel, and Hanes spokesperson, Vendela was signing autographs. A jazz trio played; a crowd of hundreds had formed. I trudged through the noisome throng and got in line. A tall, nattily attired Lord & Taylor employee told me that in order to aid the autographing process, I should write my name on the piece of paper she was handing me; she also gave me a raffle ticket, saying, ''Vendela's wearing a diamond necklace that we're raffling off.'' I asked, ''If I win, can I remove it from her neck?'' An eavesdropping shopper retorted, ''Yeah, with your teeth.''

I asked, ''If I win, can I remove it from her neck?'' An eavesdropping shopper retorted, ''Yeah, with your teeth.''

I waited in line some 20 minutes. Vendela sat atop a pink carpeted platform in a sleeveless dress. She was signing Hanes posters -- color photographs of a nude-except-for-Hanes Vendela, the subtext of which seemed to be: ''She who dons resilience hosiery will be launched into a woozy dreamscape of postcoital languor.'' When I finally reached the platform, Vendela looked slightly askance at my slip of paper: I had written Hanque on it. ''It's French for Hank,'' I told her. ''I'm hoping people will think I'm more attractive if I have a one-word name.'' I watched her try to grapple with this concept. ''Is it working for you?'' I asked. She smiled at me somewhat uncertainly and then delivered her bombshell: ''I think you're attractive no matter what your name is.'' I remarked, ''Wow.'' She signed my poster: ''To Hanque! Love and kisses, Vendela.'' Flattery having apparently jellified my powers of articulation, I reiterated, ''Wow!''

I gloated for weeks; my internal emotional dial was decidedly set on Auto-Kvell. I have attended seven other celebrity appearances at department stores since; it's like going to Elaine's, but without all the garlic. Although I have yet to achieve the level of approbation that I did at Lord & Taylor, I have often been warmed by the frictional glow of the rich and famous rubbing up against hoi polloi. I have seen Liz Taylor, promoting her Black Pearls fragrance at Macy's, fend off questions about her ''food problem.'' (''And what did you have for dinner last night?'' one customer demanded.) I have witnessed the spectacle of Eric Ripert (air-EEK repair), chef and owner of Le Bernardin, lugging an Igloo cooler stuffed with tuna tartare through the gauntlet of Macy's cosmetics department. I possess a photograph of rapper LL Cool J from his appearance at Bloomingdale's, autographed and personally inscribed to me with the message, ''Be Cool.'' Granted, small things. And yet, something.

I have also made two acquaintances with whom I may re-establish contact. I attended Macy's celebration of World History Month, which featured three African drummers, surrounded by cookware displays and asparagus forks in Macy's Cellar, pounding explosively on their drums in honor of a children's book that describes the blighted yam harvest of the Yoruba tribe in 1440. I said to one of the drummers, ''This is going to look very interesting on your resume.'' He laughed and gave me his business card.

Three days later, a sign at the Share Our Strength benefit brunch at Bloomingdale's encouraged me to tuck into some ''very special cheesecake'' prepared by Joey Reynolds, the W0R-AM radio personality. I did. It was sublime. ''I make a very special cheesecake. too,'' I told Joey, who reminds me of Joe Pesci trapped in the body of Tony Randall. ''But it's not this special.'' Joey revealed to me: ''My secret is I use a lot of nothing. Other people add lemon, rum, lime. I've cut it down to the basics. Less is more.'' (At the end of the brunch, I found Joey at the coat check, where he asked me, somewhat neurotically, ''So -- so you liked the cheesecake?'')

But pressed to single out the VIP whose intrastore appearance has provided me with the most sustenance, I would have to name Larry Harmon, the original Bozo the Clown, whom I saw at Bloomingdale's. Dressed in a double-breasted suit and boots with two-inch heels, his gray hair copiously trained over his pate, this charming 71-year-old confided to me that Golda Meir once called him and opined that if Bozo had been around 3,000 years ago, ''the Arabs and Israelis would never have fought.''

Sometimes, when I'm feeling irritable or depressed or overwhelmed by my lot in life, I form a mental image of Bozo, squirting seltzer down the Maccabees' pants in the pre-Christian Levant. It's enough to keep me going.
ENDPAPER Henry Alford is a frequent contributor to the Magazine.
